description: Borrowed from Spanish jefe (“leader, boss”), from Old French chief, from Latin caput. Doublet of chief, chef, caput, and head.

entries.meaning: (US, informal) An officer with political influence; a head or chief in government, such as a sheriff, particularly where that person is Hispanic or of Mexican descent.
examples: Antonio Rivera Cabezas was chosen vice-jefe in March 1830.

entries.meaning: (US) A boss in a business, company, or other organization.
examples: “They ain’t going to deliver the cattle across.... They’ve taken too much of a beating as it is. They’ve lost their big jefe and lots of men.”
